awd_titl_txt: Unique Continuation and Regularity of CR Mappings
awd_abstract_narration:
The main parts of the mathematics research project by Shiferaw Berhanu involve the investigation of the validity of unique continuation for solutions of systems of first order partial differential equations and second order partial differential equations. The project includes problems on the regularity of certain mappings between submanifolds in complex spaces. The second order partial differential equations under study arise in the study of electromagnetic radiation, optics, seismology, and acoustics. Some of the equations that are to be investigated are relevant to solid mechanics where they can be used to model elasto-static deformations. They are also of relevance in fluid mechanics since they can be employed to describe the motion of an incompressible viscous fluid. Results from the project have important applications to function theory of Several Complex Variables, CR Geometry, and linear as well as nonlinear partial differential equations. The project will provide several interesting problems to graduate students and young researchers.

The first main problem concerns understanding geometric conditions on two Cauchy-Riemann submanifolds that guarantee unique continuation for a CR mapping between them that vanishes to infinite order at a point. The second problem concerns the unique continuation at the boundary for solutions of real analytic, second order or higher order, elliptic partial differential equations. The third problem involves the regularity of CR mappings between Cauchy-Riemann submanifolds. The methods to be employed include the theory of analytic discs, nonlinear Fourier transforms (FBI transforms), and a precise analysis of Green's functions for the second and higher order operators under study.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of the project consist of new results on unique continuation, regularity of solutions of complex vector fields, and the strong maximum principle for CR functions. 

 The main result of the project is a positive solution of a unique continuation problem conjectured by Baouendi and Rothschild for solutions of second order elliptic partial differential equations with real analytic coefficients. This result was applied to yield a unique continuation theorem for CR mappings between embedded hypersurfaces.

A regularity result was proved for solutions of systems of tube complex vector fields. This result has an application to the holomorphic extendability of CR functions.

The outcomes led to seven papers six of which have been published and the seventh one is under review by a journal.

The Intellectual Merits of the outcomes comprise the fact that the results have important applications to function theory of several complex variables, CR Geometry, and the theory of linear partial differential equations. The second order partial differential equations studied in this project arise in many problems in analysis, geometry, applied mathematics, statistics, physics, and engineering. These equations are relevant to physically significant partial differential equations such as the wave equation, the heat equation, the Klein-Gordon equation, Maxwell's and Schrodinger's equations.

 In terms of Broader Impacts, the PI has been engaged in a number of synergistic activities including arranging for the participation of graduate students and recent Ph.D.'s in several workshops. The PI has also worked hard to help improve the recruitment and retention of graduate students from under-represented groups. 

 


Last Modified: 06/06/2022
Modified by: Shiferaw Berhanu
